questions.text: The empirical relationship between the three measures of central tendency is:
For the following distribution: Class 0-5, 5-10, 10-15, 15-20, 20-25; Frequency 10, 15, 12, 20, 9. The sum of lower limits of the median class and modal class is:
questions.explanation: Modal class (max freq 20) is 15-20 (Lower=15). Median class (N/2=33) is 10-15 (Lower=10). Sum = 25.

questions.text: If the difference of mode and median of a data is 24, then the difference of median and mean is:
questions.explanation: Mode - Median = 24. We know Mode - Mean = 3(Median - Mean). Substitute.

questions.text: The class marks of the median class of the following data (Class 10-25...85-100) is:
questions.explanation: Find N/2, locate class, find mid-point.

questions.text: If mode of the following frequency distribution is 55, then find the value of x (Class 45-60 freq 15).
The mean of the following distribution is (xi: 12, 14, 18, 20; fi: 3, 5, 8, 7):
Find the mean of the first 10 natural numbers.

Assertion (A): The arithmetic mean of the following distribution (given) is 13.81.
Reason (R): Mean = Σfx / Σf.
options: Both A and R are true and R is correct explanation
Both A and R true but R not explanation
questions.answer: (a) Both A and R are true and R is correct explanation

questions.text:
Assertion (A): If the value of mode and mean is 60 and 66 respectively, then the value of median is 64.
Reason (R): Median = (Mode + 2Mean)/3.
options: Both A and R are true
questions.answer: (c) A is true but R is false (Formula is Mode = 3Median - 2Mean). Wait, Median = (Mode+2Mean)/3 is actually correct rearrangement. So (a).

questions.text:
Assertion (A): The algebraic sum of the deviations of a frequency distribution from its mean is 0.
Reason (R): Mode of a frequency distribution cannot be determined graphically.
options: Both A and R are true
questions.answer: (c) A is true but R is false (Mode can be determined by histogram).

questions.text: The mean and mode of a frequency distribution are 28 and 16 respectively. Find the median.
Find the class marks of classes 10-25 and 35-55.
If the mean of the following distribution is 2.6, find y. (x: 1,2,3,4,5; f: 4,5,y,1,2).
In a continuous frequency distribution, if l = 32.5, f1 = 15, f0 = 12, f2 = 8 and h = 8, then find the mode.
Calculate the median salary of the data (Salary in thousands vs No of Persons).
If mode of the following frequency distribution is 55, then find the value of x.
The mode of a grouped frequency distribution is 75 and the modal class is 65-80. The frequency of the class preceding is 6 and succeeding is 8. Find frequency of modal class.
Find the mean of the following data using assumed mean method. (Class 0-10 to 40-50).
Calculate the median marks of the following data: (Marks 0-10 to 40-50).
Find the missing frequency f if the mean of the distribution is 18.

Case Study: COVID-19.
During a survey, ages of 80 patients infected by COVID were recorded. (Table given: Age below 15, 25...). 
(i) Find the modal class interval.
(ii) Find the median class interval.
(iii) Find the modal age.

Case Study: Overweight.
The weights of 35 students were recorded. (Table given).
(i) Find the median class.
(ii) Find the modal class.
(iii) Calculate median weight.

Case Study: Rainfall.
IMD observed seasonal rainfall in different subdivisions. (Table given: 200-400 to 1600-1800).
(i) Write the modal class.
(ii) Find the mean rainfall.
The median of the following data is 525. Find the values of x and y, if the total frequency is 100.
If the median of the distribution given below is 28.5, find the values of x and y. (Class 0-10 to 50-60).
The median of the following data is 868. Find the values of x and y, if the total frequency is 100.
A life insurance agent found the following data for distribution of ages of 100 policy holders. Calculate the median age.
The distribution below gives the marks of 100 students of a class, if the median marks are 24, find the frequencies f1 and f2.
